interaction_summary:
=== Purchase Information ===
Product Title: Prancer
Review Date: 2014/02/28
Store: Various  (Actor, Director)    Rated:    G    Format: DVD
Categories: Movies & TV, Holidays & Seasonal, Christmas, Classics Kids Love
Product Description: ['Product Description', 'Prancer (RPKG/DVD)', "Family entertainment. A 9-year-old girl's belief in the magic of miracles brings the joy of Christmas to her family and hometown when she finds a wounded reindeer whom she secretly nurses back to health.", ']]>', 'Amazon.com', "A reindeer doesn't have to fly to be magical to someone, and", 'Prancer', "succeeds, in its unassuming and plainspoken way, to prove that point. This 1989 family film stars Rebecca Harrell as 9-year-old Jessica, a motherless schoolgirl raised (and largely ignored) by her bereaved and embittered father (Sam Elliot), an apple farmer. While Jessica's dad struggles to keep food on the family table, the little heroine worries over the fate of a wounded reindeer she meets and wistfully identifies as a member of Santa's sled crew. The story may sound overly precious, but the film is grittier and more realistic than that. Far more concerned with wobbly family relationships than gilded escapism,", 'Prancer', 'is a rare family film that can entertain without invoking fluffy enchantment. Followed 12 years later by a sequel,', 'Prancer Returns', '.', '--Tom Keogh']
Average Rating: 4.8
Product Details: {'Genre': 'Drama', 'Format': 'Multiple Formats, NTSC, Anamorphic, Color, Dolby, DTS Surround Sound, Subtitled, Widescreen, Closed-captionedMultiple Formats, NTSC, Anamorphic, Color, Dolby, DTS Surround Sound, Subtitled, Widescreen, Closed-captioned   See more', 'Contributor': 'Various', 'Language': 'English (Dolby Digital 2.0 Surround), French (Dolby Digital 2.0 Mono)', 'Runtime': '1 hour and 43 minutes', 'Aspect Ratio': '1.85:1', 'Is Discontinued By Manufacturer': 'No', 'MPAA rating': 'G (General Audience)', 'Product Dimensions': '0.7 x 7.5 x 5.4 inches; 2.72 Ounces', 'Item model number': '1002377', 'Director': 'Various', 'Media Format': 'Multiple Formats, NTSC, Anamorphic, Color, Dolby, DTS Surround Sound, Subtitled, Widescreen, Closed-captioned', 'Run time': '1 hour and 43 minutes', 'Release date': 'October 2, 2001', 'Actors': 'Various', 'Dubbed': 'French', 'Subtitles': 'Spanish, French', 'Studio': 'WarnerBrothers', 'Number of discs': '1'}
Review Text: I had this movie in VHS format and replaced it with DVD. Without giving away the storyline, let me just say that this movie, about ideals, Christmas, the loss of a mother & a wife, tough economic times, and a special small town, are all reasons to add this gem to your movie collection. View it with the kids with no fear, but prepare for a bit of a rollercoaster of emotion, and a renewed faith in the innate good of people, and the power of faith!
Review Title: One of my favorite movies!
Rating: 5.0
--------------------------------------------------
reference_summary:
New Skills for Blind Dogs Levin, Caroline D. (Actor) Format: DVD Movies & TV, Independently Distributed, Kids & Family ['Product Description', 'Long-awaited, finally available \x97 A training film for blind-dog owners!', 'Training any dog is hard work. Training a blind dog can be extra challenging. So, when author Caroline Levin was approached by dog owners requesting help, we caught those sessions on film.', 'Whether you have a large, active dog, like Bubba, losing his vision slowly - or a small, shy dog like Leo, completely blind from detached retinas - this film can help you. Levin guides each dog and owner through the skills discussed in Chapter 8 of "Living With Blind Dogs". Additional footage includes demonstrations with more advanced dogs. Levin also discusses training theory, equipment, and dog-training issues specific to SARD dogs (confusion, lethargy, depression). CONTENTS:', 'INTRODUCTION', 'TRAINING THEORY', 'EQUIPMENT', 'CHOOSING VERBAL COMMANDS', 'NEW SKILLS The Go Slowly or Easy The Stop or Wait The Come When Called Managing Steps and Stairs Teaching the Dog to Use a Ramp Walking a Blind Dog on Leash The Forward The Pipe-Leash or Stick-leash Directional Cues \x97 And the Small Dog \x97 And the Large Dog Other Basic Skills Sit stay Down stay', 'TRAINING PUPPIES', 'TRAINING DOGS BOTH BLIND AND DEAF', 'CLOSING THOUGHTS', 'Review', '...nothing helps as much as seeing actual examples. This video offers gentle, reward-based, practical examples of training these dogs. --', 'The Oregonian, February 2005', 'a special work and I\x92m impressed with it \x85a MUST as a companion to the book "Living With Blind Dogs". --', 'Mrs. Dee Dee Rose, AKC Obedience judge and SARD-dog owner'] {'Format': 'Color, Full Screen, NTSC, Digital Sound', 'Contributor': 'Levin, Caroline D.', 'Runtime': '48 minutes', 'Package Dimensions': '7.1 x 5.42 x 0.58 inches; 2.93 Ounces', 'Media Format': 'Color, Full Screen, NTSC, Digital Sound', 'Run time': '48 minutes', 'Release date': 'April 5, 2004', 'Actors': 'Levin, Caroline D.', 'Studio': 'Lantern Publications Studios', 'Number of discs': '1'} Being the 'seeing eye person' for my own dog, Wiggles, who is an eight-year-Young Blue Heeler / cattle dog, as we deal with hereditary 'late onset' PRA (progressive retinal atrophy), I was hoping to see more familiar things that I've done to make life better/safer for Wiggles, such as padding corners at places where he has/would bump due to getting slightly 'off-center,' as well as making entrances to my home easier to 'find by nose' with scents and textures like cedar bark mulch, which has its own unique aroma.

Suggestions like making the yard more friendly for blind eyes -- in my case, that meant no more holly hedge, rose or hydrangea bushes or astilbe, and substituting equally lovely and great-fragranced old-fashioned lilac bushes for hedge, and keeping them trimmed so no sharp branches are at his eye level, and other friendly flowers like daylilies, Asiatic and Oriental lilies, which provide not only friendly foliage, but also great 'seeing eye smells' by which to guide Wiggles' nose. I've also installed 'pool noodles,' strung together with cotton clothsline cord and held at just the right height for Wiggles' shoulder by 'plant stakes' (may be procured at most 'big box' stores like KMart, WalMart, and also gardening stores, generally green-coated metal), through which the long string of pool noodles is 'threaded,' and located around the home and/or flower bed's perimeter. During the growing months, daylily foliage covers the pool noodles, but it is amazing how appreciative your blind pet will be of your efforts to help him/her maneuver safely in your yard!

Also, the video did not cover the very real dangers of water, holes, etc., that your blind friend cannot see. This includes indoor dangers like sunken tubs and the many objects that become hazards to one no longer able to see them.

The video did stress the importance of not moving furniture, and very patiently (sometimes almost too patiently, for suggestions were repeated several times) made sure the viewer was shown the few techniques more than once.

A good start to this topic, but it is hoped there will be more to come, as this is a very important subject to those who are blessed with these special friends and companions and to be their 'seeing eye people.'

We want to do our best to make their lives happy, and this is not difficult for the devoted pet owner.

Music played softly can be soothing, but the voices of two or more people can be confusing to the blind one. At times of frustration and confusion, the calming support and 'I'm here for you and love you very much' message is vital to keeping your special friend secure and content with his/her new chapter in life.

Please, love your blind dog as he/she would love you if you lost one of your senses: it's far from the end, but a new and blessed beginning to have such a role as seeing eye person. We are both just fine with our lives now and still enjoy playtime, walks, and normal life.

Don't let this minor hurdle stop you from loving and living a wonderful life with your blind pet. You'll come to learn the blessings of a profoundly special relationship -- you won't be sorry! Not bad Tammy and The Bachelor [VHS] Debbie Reynolds (Actor), Walter Brennan (Actor), Joseph Pevney (Director) & 0 more Rated: NR Format: VHS Tape Movies & TV, Genre for Featured Categories, Comedy ['Tammy and The Bachelor'] {'Is Discontinued By Manufacturer': 'No', 'Package Dimensions': '7.32 x 4.19 x 1.12 inches; 6.13 Ounces', 'Director': 'Joseph Pevney', 'Run time': '1 hour and 29 minutes', 'Release date': 'January 20, 1993', 'Date First Available': 'December 14, 2006', 'Actors': 'Debbie Reynolds, Walter Brennan, Leslie Nielsen, Mala Powers, Sidney Blackmer', 'Studio': 'Universal Studios Home Entertainment', 'Producers': 'Ross Hunter', 'Writers': 'Cid Ricketts Sumner, Oscar Brodney'} This is my all-time favorite movie and one that I've enjoyed on a regular basis for years. It's just wonderful; cannot recommend too highly! What's not to love? profile:
The user remains a nurturing and devoted pet owner, emphasizing the enhancement of their blind dog's quality of life through training, care solutions, and DIY adaptations that utilize natural elements like scents and textures. Their proactive engagement in educational content reflects a commitment to learning, specifically through detailed instructions and examples that support their pet care journey. The user also prioritizes emotional well-being, acknowledging the importance of addressing both their pet's needs and their own during transitional periods.

Recently, the user has further showcased their appreciation for classic films, purchasing a beloved family movie that resonates with themes of hope, family, and the magic of belief. This interaction highlights their nostalgia and emotional connection to cinema, suggesting that leisure activities play a significant role in their balanced lifestyle. 

The combination of nurturing tendencies, a proactive attitude toward education, and a love for meaningful entertainment underscores the user's compassionate and empathetic outlook on life. Their commitment to both pet care and personal enjoyment fosters continuous growth in their roles as a caring pet owner and a well-rounded individual, ensuring both their and their pet's quality of life is enriched.
